item.title: The Renminbi exchange rate has seen significant volatility, breaking through 7.26
item.description:
Fluctuations in the Renminbi exchange rate and the broader market decline are likely linked to global central bank policies, the Swiss National Bank’s surprise interest rate cut, US economic data performance, and adjustments in market expectations regarding inflation and interest rate cuts. These factors collectively impacted the foreign exchange and stock markets, leading to Renminbi volatility and A-share declines.

According to the link provided, the Renminbi exchange rate experienced a significant fluctuation on March 22, 2024. Here are the details:

  1. The yuan weakened at opening, with the dollar exceeding 7.24 against the offshore RMB to 7.24926 and surpassing 7.22 against the onshore RMB to 7.22360, both breaking highs seen since November 17, 2023. At the time of this report, the dollar has broken past 7.26, reaching a low of 7.2639, and the trend continues.

  2. On March 22, the central bank set the midpoint of the yuan against the dollar at 7.1004, a decrease of 62 basis points, with an expanded adjustment range

  3. Affected by multiple factors, China’s three major A-share indices opened and closed lower, with declines exceeding 1%

  4. A senior currency trader at a Hong Kong investment firm stated that foreign exchange market volatility is primarily due to the Swiss National Bank’s unexpected rate cut boosting the dollar, combined with a strong US economy and persistent inflation potentially delaying interest rate cuts, leading to an increase in the dollar index

  5. This week is a “super central bank week” for global markets, with interest rate decisions to be announced by central banks in the US, Japan, UK, Australia, and more. The Swiss National Bank’s surprise rate cut marks the first such action among G10 central banks since the pandemic began, disrupting market equilibrium.

  6. Guangda Bank financial market researcher Zhou Maohua stated that despite recent RMB fluctuations, the overall magnitude is significantly smaller than that of major currencies like the US dollar, and short-term volatility will not alter the year’s upward trend
